introduction.content: Human Papillomavirus (HPV)-associated diseases are an emerging global epidemic [1] , [2] . The role of HPV-6 and HPV-11 in the etiology of recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP), the most common benign tumor of the laryngeal epithelium, is well-established [3] , [4] . RRP lesions can occur in the oropharynx, larynx, and elsewhere in the respiratory tract [5] , significantly impacting voice production and even breathing in severe cases. Rarely, papillomas can undergo malignant transformation in the pulmonary tract, most notably in the pulmonary parenchyma [6] . RRP is a chronic, debilitating disease that is associated with substantial patient burden. Repeated surgical removal of papillomas for symptomatic management remains the mainstay of treatment and can result in significant morbidity considering the number of surgical procedures required, impact on voice, effects of repetitive anesthesia, as well as psychological impact, and financial burden [7] . Additionally, the risk of laryngeal injury increases with each surgery [8] . Current treatment of HPV-6- and HPV-11-related RRP could be improved with the addition of HPV-specific immunotherapy, which has the therapeutic potential to control or eliminate papillomas by generating immunity against HPV itself. Patients suffering from RRP have been characterized as exhibiting suppressive or regulatory immune-related functions within papillomas, as opposed to mounting a cytotoxic response against HPV infected cells [9] , [10] , [11] , [12] , [13] . Our previous studies of DNA immunotherapies directed against HPV have demonstrated the induction of potent immune responses for HPV in a pilot trial of adults with HPV-6-related RRP and in HPV-related head and neck squamous cell carcinoma as well as cervical disease, inclusive of the generation of HPV-specific cytotoxic T-cells as well as CD8+ immune cell infiltration into tumors [14] , [15] , [16] , [17] , [18] . Additionally, other groups have conducted clinical studies of RRP treatment from an immunological approach via antibody and T-cell-related platforms, with results that support an immune-based impact on disease state [19] , [20] . INO-3107 is a DNA immunotherapy encoding for antigens from both HPV-6 and HPV-11 as well as encoding for an interleukin-12 (IL-12) immune adjuvant. Here, we report full study results from a DNA-based therapy in development for RRP from a completed Phase 1/2 trial demonstrating the safety, efficacy, and immune responses of INO-3107.

7.21: The estimated mean number of surgical procedures per month was 0.35 before vaccination.
7.22: The mean intersurgical interval increased from 7.02 months before HPV vaccination to 34.45 months after HPV vaccination.
7.23: The range of intersurgical intervals was 0.30-45 months before HPV vaccination.
7.24: The range of intersurgical intervals was 2.71-82 months after HPV vaccination.
7.25: The present study supports the continued use of the HPV vaccine as an adjuvant treatment for recurrent respiratory papillomatosis.

8.1: The aim is to describe iatrogenic laryngeal injury in RRP patients receiving surgical care.

8.3: The study uses a case-control design.

8.6: Patients were separated into two cohorts based on the experience of any form of iatrogenic laryngeal injury.
8.7: Forms of iatrogenic laryngeal injury considered include anterior commissure synechiae, vocal cord scar, reduced vocal fold pliability, vocal fold motion impairment, and glottic and/or subglottic stenosis.
8.8: Adjusted logistic regressions were performed to identify factors associated with iatrogenic laryngeal injury.
8.9: Out of 199 RRP patients, 133 of them, or 66.8%, had identifiable iatrogenic laryngeal injury.
8.10: The most common injury was anterior commissure synechiae, occurring in 50.4% of patients with injury.
8.11: Reduced vocal fold pliability was another common injury, occurring in 40.6% of patients with injury.
8.12: Patients with diabetes mellitus have an increased risk of iatrogenic laryngeal injury.
8.13: Patients who received at least 10 surgeries in their lifetime have an increased risk of iatrogenic laryngeal injury.
8.14: Receiving less than 5 surgeries is protective against iatrogenic laryngeal injury.
8.15: A greater lifetime number of surgeries is a significant risk factor for iatrogenic laryngeal injury when treated as a continuous variable.
8.16: These results suggest the importance of strict glucose control for diabetic patients receiving RRP surgical care.
8.17: There is a clinical need to identify medical therapies to decrease RRP surgical frequency for patients.

13.1: Recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP) is a rare chronic disease.
13.2: RRP is caused by human papillomaviruses (HPVs) types 6 and 11.
13.3: RRP is characterized by the polarization of adaptive immune responses.
13.4: The polarization of adaptive immune responses in RRP supports persistent HPV infection.
13.5: Respiratory papillomas express elevated mRNA levels of IL-36γ compared to autologous clinically normal laryngeal tissues.
13.7: There is no evidence of inflammation in respiratory papillomas despite elevated IL-36γ mRNA levels.
13.8: Respiratory papillomas do not contain TH1-like CD4(+) T-cells.
13.9: Respiratory papillomas do not contain cytotoxic CD8(+) T-cells.
13.10: Respiratory papillomas contain a predominance of TH2-like cells.

13.17: This study provides the first evidence of the response of peripheral blood-derived iLCs to IL-36γ.
13.18: iLCs from patients with RRP had lower expression levels of the TH2-like chemokine CCL-20 when stimulated with IL-36γ compared with controls.
13.19: Patients' iLCs had decreased steady state levels of CCL-1.
13.21: CCL-1 levels in iLCs inversely correlated with the severity of RRP.

viewpoints: Patients suffering from RRP exhibit suppressive or regulatory immune-related functions within papillomas.
Patients suffering from RRP do not mount a cytotoxic response against HPV infected cells.

sentences.sentence: Our previous studies of DNA immunotherapies directed against HPV have demonstrated the induction of potent immune responses for HPV in a pilot trial of adults with HPV-6-related RRP and in HPV-related head and neck squamous cell carcinoma as well as cervical disease, inclusive of the generation of HPV-specific cytotoxic T-cells as well as CD8+ immune cell infiltration into tumors [14] , [15] , [16] , [17] , [18] .

14.1: Programmed death (PD-1) receptor-directed antibodies elicit clinical responses in approximately 20% of patients with advanced head and neck squamous cell cancer (HNSCCa).
14.2: Viral neoantigens, such as the E6/E7 proteins of HPV16/18, are attractive targets for therapeutic immunization.
14.3: Viral neoantigens, such as the E6/E7 proteins of HPV16/18, offer an immune activation strategy that may be complementary to PD-1 inhibition.
14.4: Phase Ib/II safety results of immunotherapy with MEDI0457 are reported.
14.5: Phase Ib/II tolerability results of immunotherapy with MEDI0457 are reported.
14.6: Phase Ib/II immunogenicity results of immunotherapy with MEDI0457 are reported.
14.7: MEDI0457 is a DNA immunotherapy targeting HPV16/18 E6/E7 with IL12 encoding plasmids.
14.8: MEDI0457 is delivered by electroporation with the CELLECTRA constant current device.
14.9: This sentence is incomplete and does not provide any viewpoints on its own.
14.10: MEDI0457 was associated with mild injection site reactions.
14.11: No treatment-related grade 3-5 adverse events were noted with MEDI0457.
14.12: Eighteen of 21 evaluable patients showed elevated antigen-specific T-cell activity as measured by IFNγ ELISpot.
14.13: Eighteen of 21 evaluable patients showed persistent cellular responses surpassing 100 spot-forming units (SFUs).
14.14: MEDI0457 can generate durable HPV16/18 antigen-specific peripheral immune responses.
14.15: MEDI0457 can generate durable HPV16/18 antigen-specific tumor immune responses.
14.16: This approach may be used as a complementary strategy to PD-1/PD-L1 inhibition in HPV-associated HNSCCa.
14.17: The use of this approach as a complementary strategy to PD-1/PD-L1 inhibition in HPV-associated HNSCCa may improve therapeutic outcomes.

15.1: Testing of INO-3016 in animal models confirmed immunogenicity of the DNA-based therapy.
15.2: A single-site open-label Phase 1 study was initiated for patients with HPV6-positive recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP).
15.3: Patients were dosed with INO-3106 with or without INO-9012.
15.4: INO-9012 is a DNA plasmid immunotherapy that encodes interleukin-12 (IL-12).
15.5: INO-3106 and INO-9012 were delivered intramuscularly in combination with electroporation using the CELLECTRA device.
15.6: Three patients were enrolled in the study.
15.7: Two of the three enrolled patients had recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP).
15.9: No serious adverse events related to the study therapy occurred.
15.10: All adverse events related to the study therapy were low-grade.
15.11: Injection site pain was the most common adverse event related to the study therapy.
15.12: Immunogenicity was evidenced by multiple immune assays.
15.13: The immune assays showed engagement and expansion of an HPV6-specific cellular response.
15.14: The HPV6-specific cellular response included cytotoxic T cells.
15.15: Preliminary efficacy was demonstrated in patients with recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP).
15.16: The preliminary efficacy was shown by a reduction in the need for surgical intervention for papilloma growth.
15.17: Before the intervention, both patients required surgical intervention approximately every 180 days.
15.18: One patient demonstrated a greater than three-fold increase in surgery avoidance, with 584 days between interventions.
15.19: The other patient remains completely surgery-free as of the last contact at 915 days.
15.20: The 915 days interval represents a greater than 5-fold increase in surgery interval for the second patient.
15.21: INO-3106 with and without INO-9012 was well tolerated in patients with HPV6-associated RRP aerodigestive lesions.
15.22: INO-3106 with and without INO-9012 was immunogenic in patients with HPV6-associated RRP aerodigestive lesions.
15.23: INO-3106 with and without INO-9012 demonstrated preliminary efficacy in patients with HPV6-associated RRP aerodigestive lesions.
15.24: Further clinical study of INO-3106 with and without INO-9012 is indicated.

16.1: Tumoral programmed cell death ligand-1 (PD-L1) expression is common in human papillomavirus-associated head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.
16.2: A DNA vaccine targeting HPV-16/18 E6/E7 with interleukin-12 adjuvant (MEDI0457) was combined with the PD-L1 inhibitor durvalumab.
16.3: The combination of MEDI0457 and durvalumab was assessed for enhancing HPV-specific T-cell response.
16.4: The combination of MEDI0457 and durvalumab was assessed for improving outcomes in recurrent/metastatic HPV-16/18-associated head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.
16.5: The study was a phase Ib/IIa trial.
16.6: The study involved immunotherapy-naïve patients with at least one previous platinum-containing regimen.
16.7: Patients received MEDI0457 7 mg intramuscularly with electroporation on weeks 1, 3, 7, 12, then every 8 weeks.
16.8: Patients received durvalumab 1500 mg intravenously on weeks 4, 8, 12, then every 4 weeks.
16.9: Treatment continued until confirmed progression or unacceptable toxicity.
16.10: The co-primary objectives of the study were safety and objective response rate.
16.11: The null hypothesis for the objective response rate was ORR ≤15%.
16.12: Secondary objectives included 16-week disease control rate, overall survival, and progression-free survival.
16.13: 35 patients were treated in the study.
16.14: 29 patients were response-evaluable due to confirmed HPV-associated disease and having received both agents.
16.15: The objective response rate was 27.6% with a confidence interval of 12.7-47.2%.
16.16: There were 4 complete responses and 4 partial responses.
16.17: Responses were independent of PD-L1 tumor-cell expression levels (≥25% vs <25%).
16.18: The 16-week disease control rate was 44.8% with a confidence interval of 26.5-64.3%.
16.19: Median progression-free survival was 3.5 months with a confidence interval of 1.9-9.0 months.
16.20: Median overall survival was 29.2 months with a lower limit of 15.2 months and an upper limit that was not calculable.
16.21: 80.0% of patients experienced treatment-related adverse events.
16.23: There were no grade 4 or 5 adverse events.
16.24: Adverse events resulted in discontinuation for 2 patients (5.7%).
16.25: HPV-16/18-specific T cells increased during treatment.
16.26: 4 out of 8 evaluable patients had a more than 2-fold increase in tumor-infiltrating CD8+ T cells.
16.27: MEDI0457 plus durvalumab was well tolerated.
16.28: The primary efficacy endpoint was not reached.
16.29: Clinical benefit from the treatment was encouraging.

17.1: Preventive vaccines exist for oncogenic human papillomaviruses (HPVs).
17.2: Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) is common despite the existence of preventive vaccines for oncogenic HPVs.
17.3: Current treatments for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) are ablative.
17.4: Current ablative treatments for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) can lead to long-term reproductive morbidity.
17.5: The study assessed the potential of VGX-3100 to cause histopathological regression in women with CIN2/3.
17.6: VGX-3100 consists of synthetic plasmids targeting HPV-16 and HPV-18 E6 and E7 proteins.
17.8: The efficacy of VGX-3100 was assessed in a randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase 2b study in CIN2/3 associated with HPV-16 and HPV-18.
17.9: The safety of VGX-3100 was assessed in a randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase 2b study in CIN2/3 associated with HPV-16 and HPV-18.
17.10: The immunogenicity of VGX-3100 was assessed in a randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase 2b study in CIN2/3 associated with HPV-16 and HPV-18.
17.11: Patients from 36 academic and private gynaecology practices in seven countries were included in the study.
17.12: Patients were randomised in a ratio of 3:1 to receive either 6 mg VGX-3100 or a placebo.
17.13: VGX-3100 or placebo was given intramuscularly at 0, 4, and 12 weeks.
17.14: Randomisation was stratified by age groups (<25 vs ≥25 years).
17.15: Randomisation was stratified by CIN2 versus CIN3.
17.16: A computer-generated allocation sequence (block size 4) was used for randomisation.
17.17: The funder and site personnel were masked to treatment.
17.18: The participants were masked to treatment.
17.19: The pathologists were masked to treatment.
17.20: The primary efficacy endpoint was regression to CIN1.
17.21: The primary efficacy endpoint was regression to normal pathology.
17.22: The efficacy endpoint evaluation was conducted 36 weeks after the first dose.
17.23: Per-protocol analyses were based on patients receiving three doses without protocol violations.
17.24: Modified intention-to-treat analyses were based on patients receiving at least one dose.
17.25: The safety population included all patients who received at least one dose.
17.26: The trial is registered at ClinicalTrials.gov with the number NCT01304524.
17.27: The trial is registered at EudraCT with the number 2012-001334-33.
17.28: 167 patients received either VGX-3100 or placebo between Oct 19, 2011, and July 30, 2013.
17.31: In the per-protocol analysis, 49.5% of VGX-3100 recipients had histopathological regression.
17.32: In the per-protocol analysis, 30.6% of placebo recipients had histopathological regression.
17.33: The percentage point difference in histopathological regression between VGX-3100 and placebo recipients was 19.0, with a 95% confidence interval of 1.4-36.6, and a p-value of 0.034.
17.34: In the modified intention-to-treat analysis, 48.2% of VGX-3100 recipients had histopathological regression.
17.35: In the modified intention-to-treat analysis, 30.0% of placebo recipients had histopathological regression.
17.36: The percentage point difference in histopathological regression between VGX-3100 and placebo recipients in the modified intention-to-treat analysis was 18.2, with a 95% confidence interval of 1.3-34.4, and a p-value of 0.034.
17.37: Injection-site reactions occurred in most patients.
17.38: Erythema was significantly more common in the VGX-3100 group compared to the placebo group.
17.39: Erythema occurred in 78.4% of VGX-3100 recipients.
17.40: Erythema occurred in 57.1% of placebo recipients.
17.41: The percentage point difference in erythema occurrence between VGX-3100 and placebo recipients was 21.3, with a 95% confidence interval of 5.3-37.8, and a p-value of 0.007.
17.42: VGX-3100 is the first therapeutic vaccine to show efficacy against CIN2/3 associated with HPV-16.
17.43: VGX-3100 is the first therapeutic vaccine to show efficacy against CIN2/3 associated with HPV-18.
17.44: VGX-3100 could present a non-surgical therapeutic option for CIN2/3.
17.45: VGX-3100 could change the treatment outlook for the common disease CIN2/3.
17.46: Inovio Pharmaceuticals is mentioned in the context of the study on VGX-3100.

18.1: Highly effective prophylactic vaccines have been developed against human papillomavirus serotypes 16 and 18.
18.2: Prevention of cervical dysplasia and cancer in women infected with high-risk HPV serotypes remains an unmet medical need.
18.3: Encouraging phase 1 safety results are reported for the therapeutic HPV16/18 candidate vaccine VGX-3100 delivered by in vivo electroporation.
18.4: Encouraging phase 1 tolerability results are reported for the therapeutic HPV16/18 candidate vaccine VGX-3100 delivered by in vivo electroporation.
18.5: Encouraging phase 1 immunogenicity results are reported for the therapeutic HPV16/18 candidate vaccine VGX-3100 delivered by in vivo electroporation.
18.6: Eighteen women previously treated for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade 2 or 3 received a three-dose intramuscular regimen of plasmid DNA encoding HPV16 and HPV18 E6/E7 antigens.
18.7: The plasmid DNA encoding HPV16 and HPV18 E6/E7 antigens was followed by electroporation in a dose escalation study.
18.8: The dose escalation study included doses of 0.3, 1, and 3 mg per plasmid.
18.9: Immunization with VGX-3100 was well tolerated.
18.10: There were reports of mild injection site reactions following immunization with VGX-3100.
18.11: There were no study-related serious adverse events following immunization with VGX-3100.
18.12: There were no grade 3 and 4 adverse events following immunization with VGX-3100.
18.13: No dose-limiting toxicity was noted in the study.
18.14: Pain was assessed by visual analog scale in the study.
18.15: Average pain scores decreased from 6.2 out of 10 to 1.4 within 10 minutes.
18.16: Average peak interferon-γ enzyme-linked immunospot magnitudes were highest in the 3 mg cohort.
18.17: Average peak interferon-γ enzyme-linked immunospot magnitudes were higher in the 3 mg cohort compared to the 0.3 mg cohort.
18.18: Average peak interferon-γ enzyme-linked immunospot magnitudes were higher in the 3 mg cohort compared to the 1 mg cohort.
18.19: The higher average peak interferon-γ enzyme-linked immunospot magnitudes in the 3 mg cohort suggest a trend toward a dose effect.
18.20: Flow cytometric analysis revealed the induction of HPV-specific CD8+ T cells in all cohorts.
18.21: HPV-specific CD8+ T cells efficiently loaded granzyme B in all cohorts.
18.22: HPV-specific CD8+ T cells efficiently loaded perforin in all cohorts.
18.23: HPV-specific CD8+ T cells exhibited full cytolytic functionality in all cohorts.
18.24: The data indicate that VGX-3100 is capable of driving robust immune responses to antigens from high-risk HPV serotypes.
18.25: VGX-3100 could contribute to the elimination of HPV-infected cells.
18.26: VGX-3100 could contribute to the regression of the dysplastic process.

viewpoints: Previous studies of DNA immunotherapies directed against HPV have demonstrated the induction of potent immune responses for HPV.
The potent immune responses were demonstrated in a pilot trial of adults with HPV-6-related RRP.
The potent immune responses were demonstrated in HPV-related head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.
The potent immune responses were demonstrated in cervical disease.
Potent immune responses inclusive of the generation of HPV-specific cytotoxic T-cells.
Potent immune responses inclusive of CD8+ immune cell infiltration into tumors.

sentences.sentence: Additionally, other groups have conducted clinical studies of RRP treatment from an immunological approach via antibody and T-cell-related platforms, with results that support an immune-based impact on disease state [19] , [20] .

19.1: Recurrent respiratory papillomatosis is a rare neoplastic disorder.
19.2: Recurrent respiratory papillomatosis is a debilitating disorder.
19.3: Recurrent respiratory papillomatosis is caused by chronic infection with human papillomavirus type 6 or 11.
19.4: Recurrent respiratory papillomatosis is characterized by the growth of papillomas in the upper aerodigestive tract.
19.5: There is no approved medical therapy for recurrent respiratory papillomatosis.
19.6: Patients with recurrent respiratory papillomatosis require repeated debulking procedures to maintain voice function.
19.7: Patients with recurrent respiratory papillomatosis require repeated debulking procedures to maintain airway function.
19.8: PRGN-2012 is a gorilla adenovirus immune-therapeutic.
19.9: PRGN-2012 is capable of enhancing HPV 6/11-specific T cell immunity.
19.10: The study is a first-in-human, phase 1 study of adjuvant PRGN-2012 treatment.
19.11: The study involves adult patients with severe, aggressive recurrent respiratory papillomatosis.
19.12: The study demonstrates the overall safety of PRGN-2012.
19.13: The study demonstrates a clinically meaningful benefit observed with PRGN-2012.
19.14: There is a 50% complete response rate in patients treated with PRGN-2012 at the highest dose.
19.15: Responders to PRGN-2012 demonstrate greater expansion of peripheral HPV-specific T cells compared with nonresponders.
19.16: Additional correlative studies identify an association between reduced baseline papilloma HPV gene expression and greater interferon responses.
19.17: Additional correlative studies identify an association between reduced baseline papilloma HPV gene expression and expression of unspecified factors.

20.1: Recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP) is a rare benign chronic disease of the larynx.
20.2: Recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP) is etiologically linked with the infection of low-risk human papillomavirus (HPV).
20.3: Combination of surgical and immunomodulatory therapy for recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP) has limited success.
20.4: The possible use of prophylactic HPV vaccine that includes HPV-6 and HPV-11 antigens has been studied for recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP).
20.5: This study aimed to evaluate if HPV vaccination is associated with a lower number of recurrences requiring surgical intervention in patients with new and recurrent recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP).
20.6: This study was a non-placebo-controlled intervention study.
20.7: Enrollment data for the study were collected from October 2011 to August 2013.
20.8: Patients were followed up at 1 month after the third dose of the HPV vaccine.
20.9: Patients were followed up at 12 months after the third dose of the HPV vaccine.
20.10: Patients were followed up at 5 years after the third dose of the HPV vaccine.
20.11: Patients were clinically monitored until December 31, 2018.
20.12: Data from the study were analyzed from 2019 to 2021.
20.13: A total of 50 adults with active recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP) were enrolled in the study.
20.14: The 50 adults with active recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP) were followed up in referral centers.
20.15: Follow-up data for 42 patients were available for the final outcome of the study.
20.16: Eight patients who did not fulfill the study protocol were excluded.
20.17: All patients received the HPV vaccine as an adjuvant treatment.
20.18: All patients were clinically followed up.
20.19: Surgical removal via direct laryngoscopy was indicated when recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP) progression was detected.
20.20: Surgical removal via direct laryngoscopy was indicated when a significant recurrent lesion was detected.
20.21: No adjuvant therapy with antiviral agents was used.
20.22: No adjuvant therapy with biological agents was used.
20.23: The study compared the prevaccination positivity for HPV-specific antibodies.
20.24: The study compared the postvaccination positivity for HPV-specific antibodies.
20.25: The main outcome of the study was the difference in the frequency of recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP) recurrences in the prevaccination period.
20.26: The main outcome of the study was the difference in the frequency of recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP) recurrences in the postvaccination period.
20.27: A total of 50 patients with recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP) were enrolled in the study.
20.28: The median age of the patients enrolled in the study was 41.5 years with a standard deviation of 12.3 years.
20.29: The age range of the patients enrolled in the study was 21 to 73 years.
20.30: There were 39 men (78%) enrolled in the study.
20.31: There were 11 women (22%) enrolled in the study.
20.32: After HPV vaccination, patients with previously no HPV-specific antibodies showed seroconversion.
20.33: After HPV vaccination, all patients developed 100-fold higher levels of HPV vaccine type-specific antibodies compared with the prevaccination period.
20.34: In patients with recurrent recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP), there was a decreased frequency of recurrences requiring surgical treatment after vaccination.
20.35: The frequency of recurrences requiring surgical treatment decreased from 0.85 to 0.36 recurrences per year after vaccination in patients with recurrent recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP).
20.36: No difference in postvaccination recurrences was found between patients with newly diagnosed recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP) and those with recurrent RRP.
20.37: In this nonrandomized clinical trial, the frequency of recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP) recurrences was significantly lower after HPV vaccination.
20.38: Patients with recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP) had a reduced burden of disease after HPV vaccination.
20.39: No difference was detected in the frequency of recurrent postvaccination lesions in patients with newly diagnosed and recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP).
20.40: Both groups of patients with newly diagnosed and recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP) showed equal benefit following HPV vaccination.
20.41: These findings suggest that the earlier patients with recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP) receive the HPV vaccine, the sooner they may show a reduced burden of disease.
20.42: The study has the EudraCT Identifier: 2011-002667-14.
20.43: The study has the ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT01375868.

viewpoints: Other groups have conducted clinical studies of RRP treatment from an immunological approach via antibody and T-cell-related platforms.
The clinical study results support an immune-based impact on the RRP disease state.

sentences.sentence: INO-3107 is a DNA immunotherapy encoding for antigens from both HPV-6 and HPV-11 as well as encoding for an interleukin-12 (IL-12) immune adjuvant.
viewpoints: INO-3107 is a DNA immunotherapy encoding for antigens from both HPV-6 and HPV-11.
INO-3107 encodes for an interleukin-12 (IL-12) immune adjuvant.

sentences.sentence: Here, we report full study results from a DNA-based therapy in development for RRP from a completed Phase 1/2 trial demonstrating the safety, efficacy, and immune responses of INO-3107.
viewpoints: The report includes full study results from a DNA-based therapy in development for RRP.
The results are from a completed Phase 1/2 trial.
The trial demonstrates the safety of INO-3107.
The trial demonstrates the efficacy of INO-3107.
The trial demonstrates the immune responses of INO-3107.
